body_markdown: Python is the primary language for the Data Science Teams at Stack Overflow. This document is a style guide for how Python code is written at Stack Overflow.
title: Python Style Guide2
body: Python is the primary language for the Data Science Teams at Stack Overflow. This document is a style guide for how Python code is written at Stack Overflow.

body_markdown:
**Mimecast for Outlook: Sending/Requesting Attachments via Large File Send**

You can request a message recipient to send attachments safely and securely via Large File Receive.

You can send attachments safely and securely via Large File Send in Mimecast for Outlook.

|  |  |
| --- | --- |
| **Note:** | From Mimecast for Outlook v7.1, the maximum number of attachments that can be attached to a message using Large File Send is 100. If you have more than 100 attachments, we recommend using a ZIP archive. |

**Sending Attachments via Large File Send**
=

![Mimecast for Outlook Sending Attachments via Large File Send](https://community.mimecast.com/servlet/rtaImage?eid=ka03l0000013Njx&feoid=00N3l00000FQXUa&refid=0EM3l000002SS0T)

To send attachments via Large File Send from the Microsoft Outlook client :

1. Create a ***Message***.
2. Click on the ***Mimecast*** tab.
3. Click on the ***Attach Large Files*** icon.
4. Select the ***Files*** you want to attach.

|  |  |
| --- | --- |
| **Note:** | The selected files are attached to the message with a notification that they will be sent via Large File Send. The file extensions are changes to .LFS meaning you can't preview them. If you want to ensure you're sending the correct files, check them before selecting them. |

5. Click the ***Send*** button.
6. Amend the ***Large File Send*** options as required:

|  |  |
| --- | --- |
| **Note:** | Your administrator may enforce some or all of these settings, meaning you cannot override them. |

| Field / Option | Description |
| --- | --- |
| Expiry Access to the Files After | Select the expiry date of the Large File Send request from the drop down. The actual expiry date is displayed to the right of the field. Once the specified date has been reached, the file can no longer be accessed via Large File Send. The "Custom" option al- lows you to set an expiry date that doesn't fit any of the other options (e.g. 28 days) but the specified value cannot be more than 90 days. |
| Notify Me When the Files are Accessed | If selected, you are notified when the recipient accesses the files via the Large File Send portal. |
| Send me a Link to the Files | If selected, you are sent a link to the files in the Large File Send portal. |
| Invite Recipients to Send me Large Files | If selected, the recipient can send file attachments back to you via Large File Send. They don't have to be Mimecast customers to do this. This functionality is useful when sending a file for comment or approval. |
| Use an Access Key for Additional File Security | If selected, the recipient must authenticate themselves by using an access key, sent to them by the Large File Send portal, before being able to access the files. |

7. Click on the ***Send***button. A progress notification popup dialog is displayed. This automatically closes when the message is successfully sent, and a notification popup message is displayed.

**Requesting Large File Attachments**
=

Benefits
-

* A message recipient doesn't need to be a Mimecast for Outlook or even a Mimecast user. They'll receive instructions in the message to upload the files to the Large File Send portal.
* Increased file security can be added by getting recipients to request an access key to access the Large File Receive portal. The key is emailed to the recipient's email address and must be entered to access the portal

![Mimecast for Outlook Requesting Large File Attachments](https://community.mimecast.com/servlet/rtaImage?eid=ka03l000000zGeC&feoid=00N3l00000FQXUa&refid=0EM3l000002SRzt)

To request a large file to be sent:

1. Click on ***New Email*** to create a message as normal.
2. Click on the ***Mimecast***ribbon.
3. Click on the ***Request Large Files*** icon.
4. Enter the recipient's ***Email Address*** and add a subject.
5. Click on the ***Send***button. The Large File Receive dialog displays.  
   ![Mimecast for Outlook Requesting Large File Attachments](https://community.mimecast.com/servlet/rtaImage?eid=ka03l000000zGeC&feoid=00N3l00000FQXUa&refid=0EM3l000002SRzu)
6. Complete the dialog as required:
   * ***Expire Access to Files After*** - All requests to share large files are subject to a time limit. Specify a value from the drop down list to specify the time frame recipients have to access the requested file. Once that period has passed, recipients are unable to access the file.
   * ***Use an Access Key for Additional File Security*** - If selected, recipients require an access key to upload the requested file. Instructions for requesting the access key is included in the message the recipient receives.
7. Click the ***OK***button.
8. Click the ***Send***button. This:
   * Sends an email to your inbox confirming that the Large File Send invitation message has been sent to the recipient.
   * Sends the recipient an email containing an attachment. Once opened, the attachment contains complete instructions on how to send the Large File Send attachment as requested:  
     ![Mimecast for Outlook Requesting Large File Attachments_1](https://community.mimecast.com/servlet/rtaImage?eid=ka03l000000zGeC&feoid=00N3l00000FQXUa&refid=0EM3l000002SRzv)

Uploading an Attachment
-

![Mimecast for Outlook Requesting Large File Attachments_1](https://community.mimecast.com/servlet/rtaImage?eid=ka03l000000zGeC&feoid=00N3l00000FQXUa&refid=0EM3l000002SRzw)

If you have been requested to upload a file using Large File Send:

1. Open the message you'll receive from the sender.
2. Open the ***Mimecast Large File Send Instructions*** attachment.
3. Click on the ***Upload Files*** link in the attachment. The Large File Send portal is opened in your browser.
4. If the sender has requested you get an access key, click the ***Get Access Key***button. An access key is emailed to your email address.

|  |  |
| --- | --- |
| **Note:** | If an access key was not requested, proceed to step 6. |

 5. Copy and paste the access key into the ***Enter Access Key*** field.
 6. Click the ***Log In*** button.
 7. Click the ***Add Files*** button to select the files to attach.
 8. Select the required files, and click the ***Open***button.
 9. Optionally, add a message in the ***Add Message*** section.
10. Click the ***Send***button. A message is displayed in the portal when the message has been sent, and the portal can be closed.

**ESCALATION:**

If unable to send or receive attachments escalate to Mimecast queue.

[This is a link to the full ServiceNow article](https://refinitiv.service-now.com/sp/?id=kb_article&sys_id=63ec5b2787d8fd50b173c88f8bbb3525)

body:
Mimecast for Outlook: Sending/Requesting Attachments via Large File Send

You can request a message recipient to send attachments safely and securely via Large File Receive.

You can send attachments safely and securely via Large File Send in Mimecast for Outlook.
Note: From Mimecast for Outlook v7.1, the maximum number of attachments that can be attached to a message using Large File Send is 100. If you have more than 100 attachments, we recommend using a ZIP archive.
Sending Attachments via Large File Send

To send attachments via Large File Send from the Microsoft Outlook client :

  1. Create a Message.
  2. Click on the Mimecast tab.
  3. Click on the Attach Large Files icon.
  4. Select the Files you want to attach.
Note: The selected files are attached to the message with a notification that they will be sent via Large File Send. The file extensions are changes to .LFS meaning you can't preview them. If you want to ensure you're sending the correct files, check them before selecting them.
  1. Click the Send button.
  2. Amend the Large File Send options as required:
Note: Your administrator may enforce some or all of these settings, meaning you cannot override them.
Field / Option Description
Expiry Access to the Files After Select the expiry date of the Large File Send request from the drop down. The actual expiry date is displayed to the right of the field. Once the specified date has been reached, the file can no longer be accessed via Large File Send. The "Custom" option al- lows you to set an expiry date that doesn't fit any of the other options (e.g. 28 days) but the specified value cannot be more than 90 days.
Notify Me When the Files are Accessed If selected, you are notified when the recipient accesses the files via the Large File Send portal.
Send me a Link to the Files If selected, you are sent a link to the files in the Large File Send portal.
Invite Recipients to Send me Large Files If selected, the recipient can send file attachments back to you via Large File Send. They don't have to be Mimecast customers to do this. This functionality is useful when sending a file for comment or approval.
Use an Access Key for Additional File Security If selected, the recipient must authenticate themselves by using an access key, sent to them by the Large File Send portal, before being able to access the files.
  1. Click on the Sendbutton. A progress notification popup dialog is displayed. This automatically closes when the message is successfully sent, and a notification popup message is displayed.
Requesting Large File Attachments Benefits
  • A message recipient doesn't need to be a Mimecast for Outlook or even a Mimecast user. They'll receive instructions in the message to upload the files to the Large File Send portal.
  • Increased file security can be added by getting recipients to request an access key to access the Large File Receive portal. The key is emailed to the recipient's email address and must be entered to access the portal

To request a large file to be sent:

  1. Click on New Email to create a message as normal.
  2. Click on the Mimecastribbon.
  3. Click on the Request Large Files icon.
  4. Enter the recipient's Email Address and add a subject.
  5. Click on the Sendbutton. The Large File Receive dialog displays.
  6. Complete the dialog as required:
    • Expire Access to Files After - All requests to share large files are subject to a time limit. Specify a value from the drop down list to specify the time frame recipients have to access the requested file. Once that period has passed, recipients are unable to access the file.
    • Use an Access Key for Additional File Security - If selected, recipients require an access key to upload the requested file. Instructions for requesting the access key is included in the message the recipient receives.
  7. Click the OKbutton.
  8. Click the Sendbutton. This:
    • Sends an email to your inbox confirming that the Large File Send invitation message has been sent to the recipient.
    • Sends the recipient an email containing an attachment. Once opened, the attachment contains complete instructions on how to send the Large File Send attachment as requested:
Uploading an Attachment

If you have been requested to upload a file using Large File Send:

  1. Open the message you'll receive from the sender.
  2. Open the Mimecast Large File Send Instructions attachment.
  3. Click on the Upload Files link in the attachment. The Large File Send portal is opened in your browser.
  4. If the sender has requested you get an access key, click the Get Access Keybutton. An access key is emailed to your email address.
Note: If an access key was not requested, proceed to step 6.
  1. Copy and paste the access key into the Enter Access Key field.
  2. Click the Log In button.
  3. Click the Add Files button to select the files to attach.
  4. Select the required files, and click the Openbutton.
  5. Optionally, add a message in the Add Message section.
  6. Click the Sendbutton. A message is displayed in the portal when the message has been sent, and the portal can be closed.

ESCALATION:

If unable to send or receive attachments escalate to Mimecast queue.

body_markdown:
· **User domain password will not be reset** with this procedure

· Verify security questions and answers before unlocking of BitLocker

· Advanced Help Desk access requires:

· Support agent’s TEN\\AU account must have proper AD group membership

· Support agent’s web browser be launched with their TEN\\AU account

· Advanced Help Desk is only for use when using accessing as a standard Help Desk user is unable to retrieve the Recovery Key for a workstation due to no/incorrect MBAM listed ‘Device User’.

**[Resolution](https://thomsonreuters.service-now.com/sp?id=kb_article&sys_id=04c0aafcdb746fc057b25d30cf9619ad)**
=

The BitLocker recover screen can be seen below showing the location of the Recover key ID information that will be needed from the customer.

Retrieve\*\*[Recovery Key](https://thomsonreuters.service-now.com/sp?id=kb_article&sys_id=04c0aafcdb746fc057b25d30cf9619ad)\*\*
=

1. Agent opens web browser using their TEN\\AU account

2. Agent connects to web address: <http://c288sdembam1.ten.thomsonreuters.com/helpdesk/KeyRecoveryPage.aspx>

3. Agent enters the first 8 characters of the ‘Recovery key ID” provided by the customer into the Key ID field.

![](https://refinitiv.service-now.com/sys_attachment.do?sys_id=495aeedadb629410d77b4a28139619c2)

4.Agent verifies the what was done prior to this issue happening to determine plausible reason for lockout, then selects the appropriate option under Reason for Drive Unlock. Once the reason is determined, select it from the dropdown list.

![](https://refinitiv.service-now.com/sys_attachment.do?sys_id=cd5aeedadb629410d77b4a28139619f5)  
NOTE: The most common reasons are likely “Operating System files modified”, “BIOS changed” and “Lost PIN”. If unknown, select Operating System files modified.

1. Operating System Boot Order changed

2. BIOS changed

3. Operating System files modified

4. Lost Startup Key

5. Lost PIN

6. TPM Reset

7. Lost Passphrase

8. Lost Smartcard

9. Other

5.Agent clicks Submit.

![](https://refinitiv.service-now.com/sys_attachment.do?sys_id=495aeedadb629410d77b4a28139619f7)

NOTE: If recovery key is not found or the user is not valid for the drive, verify that the information entered for User Domain, User ID, and Key ID are correct. If the caller is noted by BitLocker as a user of the workstation, then the customer that is the user of the workstation will need to request the Recovery Key.

GSD provides the customer with the 48-digit Drive Recovery Key provided. The key is numerical only and is made of 8 sets of 6 numbers and the hyphens are not typed

XXXXXX-XXXXXX-XXXXXX-XXXXXX-XXXXXX-XXXXXX-XXXXXX-XXXXXX

  
7.After putting in the Recovery Key on the affected workstation, customer should press the Enter key.

8.Windows should continue to load.

**For GSD:**

· Service Desk Analyst or Workplace Engineers who do not have access to the MBAM HelpDesk web address: <http://c288sdembam1.ten.thomsonreuters.com/helpdesk/KeyRecoveryPage.aspx>

· Add the user's U ID (UEmp ID) to group TEN-DG-APP-MBAM-GSD-ALL

Escalation:

TCS- REMOTE-SUPPORT or TCS-TECHBAR (if necessary)  TCS-APP-MALWARE

[This is a link to the full ServiceNow article](https://refinitiv.service-now.com/sp/?id=kb_article&sys_id=aab7f192db227450005c0704ca9619d9)
title: Test customer Markdown
body:
· User domain password will not be reset with this procedure

· Verify security questions and answers before unlocking of BitLocker

· Advanced Help Desk access requires:

· Support agent’s TEN\AU account must have proper AD group membership

· Support agent’s web browser be launched with their TEN\AU account

· Advanced Help Desk is only for use when using accessing as a standard Help Desk user is unable to retrieve the Recovery Key for a workstation due to no/incorrect MBAM listed ‘Device User’.

Resolution

The BitLocker recover screen can be seen below showing the location of the Recover key ID information that will be needed from the customer.

Retrieve**Recovery Key**

  1. Agent opens web browser using their TEN\AU account

  2. Agent connects to web address: http://c288sdembam1.ten.thomsonreuters.com/helpdesk/KeyRecoveryPage.aspx

  3. Agent enters the first 8 characters of the ‘Recovery key ID” provided by the customer into the Key ID field.

4.Agent verifies the what was done prior to this issue happening to determine plausible reason for lockout, then selects the appropriate option under Reason for Drive Unlock. Once the reason is determined, select it from the dropdown list.


NOTE: The most common reasons are likely “Operating System files modified”, “BIOS changed” and “Lost PIN”. If unknown, select Operating System files modified.

  1. Operating System Boot Order changed

  2. BIOS changed

  3. Operating System files modified

  4. Lost Startup Key

  5. Lost PIN

  6. TPM Reset

  7. Lost Passphrase

  8. Lost Smartcard

  9. Other

5.Agent clicks Submit.

NOTE: If recovery key is not found or the user is not valid for the drive, verify that the information entered for User Domain, User ID, and Key ID are correct. If the caller is noted by BitLocker as a user of the workstation, then the customer that is the user of the workstation will need to request the Recovery Key.

GSD provides the customer with the 48-digit Drive Recovery Key provided. The key is numerical only and is made of 8 sets of 6 numbers and the hyphens are not typed

XXXXXX-XXXXXX-XXXXXX-XXXXXX-XXXXXX-XXXXXX-XXXXXX-XXXXXX

7.After putting in the Recovery Key on the affected workstation, customer should press the Enter key.

8.Windows should continue to load.

For GSD:

· Service Desk Analyst or Workplace Engineers who do not have access to the MBAM HelpDesk web address: http://c288sdembam1.ten.thomsonreuters.com/helpdesk/KeyRecoveryPage.aspx

· Add the user's U ID (UEmp ID) to group TEN-DG-APP-MBAM-GSD-ALL

Escalation:

TCS- REMOTE-SUPPORT or TCS-TECHBAR (if necessary) TCS-APP-MALWARE

This is a link to the full ServiceNow article

body_markdown:
**Mimecast for Outlook: Sending/Requesting Attachments via Large File Send**

You can request a message recipient to send attachments safely and securely via Large File Receive.

You can send attachments safely and securely via Large File Send in Mimecast for Outlook.

|  |  |
| --- | --- |
| **Note:** | From Mimecast for Outlook v7.1, the maximum number of attachments that can be attached to a message using Large File Send is 100. If you have more than 100 attachments, we recommend using a ZIP archive. |

**Sending Attachments via Large File Send**
=

![Mimecast for Outlook Sending Attachments via Large File Send](https://community.mimecast.com/servlet/rtaImage?eid=ka03l0000013Njx&feoid=00N3l00000FQXUa&refid=0EM3l000002SS0T)

To send attachments via Large File Send from the Microsoft Outlook client :

1. Create a ***Message***.
2. Click on the ***Mimecast*** tab.
3. Click on the ***Attach Large Files*** icon.
4. Select the ***Files*** you want to attach.

|  |  |
| --- | --- |
| **Note:** | The selected files are attached to the message with a notification that they will be sent via Large File Send. The file extensions are changes to .LFS meaning you can't preview them. If you want to ensure you're sending the correct files, check them before selecting them. |

5. Click the ***Send*** button.
6. Amend the ***Large File Send*** options as required:

|  |  |
| --- | --- |
| **Note:** | Your administrator may enforce some or all of these settings, meaning you cannot override them. |

| Field / Option | Description |
| --- | --- |
| Expiry Access to the Files After | Select the expiry date of the Large File Send request from the drop down. The actual expiry date is displayed to the right of the field. Once the specified date has been reached, the file can no longer be accessed via Large File Send. The "Custom" option al- lows you to set an expiry date that doesn't fit any of the other options (e.g. 28 days) but the specified value cannot be more than 90 days. |
| Notify Me When the Files are Accessed | If selected, you are notified when the recipient accesses the files via the Large File Send portal. |
| Send me a Link to the Files | If selected, you are sent a link to the files in the Large File Send portal. |
| Invite Recipients to Send me Large Files | If selected, the recipient can send file attachments back to you via Large File Send. They don't have to be Mimecast customers to do this. This functionality is useful when sending a file for comment or approval. |
| Use an Access Key for Additional File Security | If selected, the recipient must authenticate themselves by using an access key, sent to them by the Large File Send portal, before being able to access the files. |

7. Click on the ***Send***button. A progress notification popup dialog is displayed. This automatically closes when the message is successfully sent, and a notification popup message is displayed.

**Requesting Large File Attachments**
=

Benefits
-

* A message recipient doesn't need to be a Mimecast for Outlook or even a Mimecast user. They'll receive instructions in the message to upload the files to the Large File Send portal.
* Increased file security can be added by getting recipients to request an access key to access the Large File Receive portal. The key is emailed to the recipient's email address and must be entered to access the portal

![Mimecast for Outlook Requesting Large File Attachments](https://community.mimecast.com/servlet/rtaImage?eid=ka03l000000zGeC&feoid=00N3l00000FQXUa&refid=0EM3l000002SRzt)

To request a large file to be sent:

1. Click on ***New Email*** to create a message as normal.
2. Click on the ***Mimecast***ribbon.
3. Click on the ***Request Large Files*** icon.
4. Enter the recipient's ***Email Address*** and add a subject.
5. Click on the ***Send***button. The Large File Receive dialog displays.  
   ![Mimecast for Outlook Requesting Large File Attachments](https://community.mimecast.com/servlet/rtaImage?eid=ka03l000000zGeC&feoid=00N3l00000FQXUa&refid=0EM3l000002SRzu)
6. Complete the dialog as required:
   * ***Expire Access to Files After*** - All requests to share large files are subject to a time limit. Specify a value from the drop down list to specify the time frame recipients have to access the requested file. Once that period has passed, recipients are unable to access the file.
   * ***Use an Access Key for Additional File Security*** - If selected, recipients require an access key to upload the requested file. Instructions for requesting the access key is included in the message the recipient receives.
7. Click the ***OK***button.
8. Click the ***Send***button. This:
   * Sends an email to your inbox confirming that the Large File Send invitation message has been sent to the recipient.
   * Sends the recipient an email containing an attachment. Once opened, the attachment contains complete instructions on how to send the Large File Send attachment as requested:  
     ![Mimecast for Outlook Requesting Large File Attachments_1](https://community.mimecast.com/servlet/rtaImage?eid=ka03l000000zGeC&feoid=00N3l00000FQXUa&refid=0EM3l000002SRzv)

Uploading an Attachment
-

![Mimecast for Outlook Requesting Large File Attachments_1](https://community.mimecast.com/servlet/rtaImage?eid=ka03l000000zGeC&feoid=00N3l00000FQXUa&refid=0EM3l000002SRzw)

If you have been requested to upload a file using Large File Send:

1. Open the message you'll receive from the sender.
2. Open the ***Mimecast Large File Send Instructions*** attachment.
3. Click on the ***Upload Files*** link in the attachment. The Large File Send portal is opened in your browser.
4. If the sender has requested you get an access key, click the ***Get Access Key***button. An access key is emailed to your email address.

|  |  |
| --- | --- |
| **Note:** | If an access key was not requested, proceed to step 6. |

 5. Copy and paste the access key into the ***Enter Access Key*** field.
 6. Click the ***Log In*** button.
 7. Click the ***Add Files*** button to select the files to attach.
 8. Select the required files, and click the ***Open***button.
 9. Optionally, add a message in the ***Add Message*** section.
10. Click the ***Send***button. A message is displayed in the portal when the message has been sent, and the portal can be closed.

**ESCALATION:**

If unable to send or receive attachments escalate to Mimecast queue.

Mimecast for Outlook: Sending/Requesting Attachments via Large File Send

You can request a message recipient to send attachments safely and securely via Large File Receive.

You can send attachments safely and securely via Large File Send in Mimecast for Outlook.
Note: From Mimecast for Outlook v7.1, the maximum number of attachments that can be attached to a message using Large File Send is 100. If you have more than 100 attachments, we recommend using a ZIP archive.
Sending Attachments via Large File Send

To send attachments via Large File Send from the Microsoft Outlook client :

  1. Create a Message.

  4. Select the Files you want to attach.
Note: The selected files are attached to the message with a notification that they will be sent via Large File Send. The file extensions are changes to .LFS meaning you can't preview them. If you want to ensure you're sending the correct files, check them before selecting them.
  1. Click the Send button.
  2. Amend the Large File Send options as required:
Note: Your administrator may enforce some or all of these settings, meaning you cannot override them.
Field / Option Description
Expiry Access to the Files After Select the expiry date of the Large File Send request from the drop down. The actual expiry date is displayed to the right of the field. Once the specified date has been reached, the file can no longer be accessed via Large File Send. The "Custom" option al- lows you to set an expiry date that doesn't fit any of the other options (e.g. 28 days) but the specified value cannot be more than 90 days.

  1. Click on the Sendbutton. A progress notification popup dialog is displayed. This automatically closes when the message is successfully sent, and a notification popup message is displayed.
Requesting Large File Attachments Benefits
  • A message recipient doesn't need to be a Mimecast for Outlook or even a Mimecast user. They'll receive instructions in the message to upload the files to the Large File Send portal.
  • Increased file security can be added by getting recipients to request an access key to access the Large File Receive portal. The key is emailed to the recipient's email address and must be entered to access the portal

To request a large file to be sent:

  1. Click on New Email to create a message as normal.
  2. Click on the Mimecastribbon.
  3. Click on the Request Large Files icon.

    • Expire Access to Files After - All requests to share large files are subject to a time limit. Specify a value from the drop down list to specify the time frame recipients have to access the requested file. Once that period has passed, recipients are unable to access the file.

  1. Open the message you'll receive from the sender.

Note: If an access key was not requested, proceed to step 6.
  1. Copy and paste the access key into the Enter Access Key field.
  2. Click the Log In button.
  3. Click the Add Files button to select the files to attach.
  4. Select the required files, and click the Openbutton.
  5. Optionally, add a message in the Add Message section.
  6. Click the Sendbutton. A message is displayed in the portal when the message has been sent, and the portal can be closed.

ESCALATION:

If unable to send or receive attachments escalate to Mimecast queue.

This is a link to the full ServiceNow article

body_markdown:
**Mimecast for Outlook: Sending/Requesting Attachments via Large File Send**  
  
  
You can request a message recipient to send attachments safely and securely via Large File Receive.  
  
  
You can send attachments safely and securely via Large File Send in Mimecast for Outlook.   
  
  
  
  
|           |                                                                                                                                                                                                            |
| --------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| **Note:** | From Mimecast for Outlook v7.1, the maximum number of attachments that can be attached to a message using Large File Send is 100. If you have more than 100 attachments, we recommend using a ZIP archive. |
  
  
**Sending Attachments via Large File Send**  
===========================================  
  
  
![Mimecast for Outlook Sending Attachments via Large File Send](https://community.mimecast.com/servlet/rtaImage?eid=ka03l0000013Njx&feoid=00N3l00000FQXUa&refid=0EM3l000002SS0T)   
  
  
To send attachments via Large File Send from the Microsoft Outlook client :  
  
  
1. Create a ***Message***.  
2. Click on the ***Mimecast*** tab.  
3. Click on the ***Attach Large Files*** icon.  
4. Select the ***Files*** you want to attach.  
  
|           |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  |
| --------- | -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| **Note:** | The selected files are attached to the message with a notification that they will be sent via Large File Send. The file extensions are changes to .LFS meaning you can't preview them. If you want to ensure you're sending the correct files, check them before selecting them. |
5. Click the ***Send*** button.  
6. Amend the ***Large File Send*** options as required:  
  
|           |                                                                                                 |
| --------- | ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| **Note:** | Your administrator may enforce some or all of these settings, meaning you cannot override them. |
  
  
  
| Field / Option                                 | Description                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     |
| ---------------------------------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Expiry Access to the Files After               | Select the expiry date of the Large File Send request from the drop down. The actual expiry date is displayed to the right of the field. Once the specified date has been reached, the file can no longer be accessed via Large File Send. The "Custom" option al- lows you to set an expiry date that doesn't fit any of the other options (e.g. 28 days) but the specified value cannot be more than 90 days. |
| Notify Me When the Files are Accessed          | If selected, you are notified when the recipient accesses the files via the Large File Send portal.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             |
| Send me a Link to the Files                    | If selected, you are sent a link to the files in the Large File Send portal.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    |
| Invite Recipients to Send me Large Files       | If selected, the recipient can send file attachments back to you via Large File Send. They don't have to be Mimecast customers to do this. This functionality is useful when sending a file for comment or approval.                                                                                                                                                                                            |
| Use an Access Key for Additional File Security | If selected, the recipient must authenticate themselves by using an access key, sent to them by the Large File Send portal, before being able to access the files.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              |
7. Click on the ***Send***button. A progress notification popup dialog is displayed. This automatically closes when the message is successfully sent, and a notification popup message is displayed.  
  
  
**Requesting Large File Attachments**  
=====================================  
  
  
Benefits  
--------  
  
  
* A message recipient doesn't need to be a Mimecast for Outlook or even a Mimecast user. They'll receive instructions in the message to upload the files to the Large File Send portal.  
* Increased file security can be added by getting recipients to request an access key to access the Large File Receive portal. The key is emailed to the recipient's email address and must be entered to access the portal  
  
  
![Mimecast for Outlook Requesting Large File Attachments](https://community.mimecast.com/servlet/rtaImage?eid=ka03l000000zGeC&feoid=00N3l00000FQXUa&refid=0EM3l000002SRzt)   
  
  
To request a large file to be sent:  
  
  
1. Click on ***New Email*** to create a message as normal.  
2. Click on the ***Mimecast***ribbon.  
3. Click on the ***Request Large Files*** icon.  
4. Enter the recipient's ***Email Address*** and add a subject.  
5. Click on the ***Send***button. The Large File Receive dialog displays.  
![Mimecast for Outlook Requesting Large File Attachments](https://community.mimecast.com/servlet/rtaImage?eid=ka03l000000zGeC&feoid=00N3l00000FQXUa&refid=0EM3l000002SRzu)  
6. Complete the dialog as required:  
	* ***Expire Access to Files After*** - All requests to share large files are subject to a time limit. Specify a value from the drop down list to specify the time frame recipients have to access the requested file. Once that period has passed, recipients are unable to access the file.  
	* ***Use an Access Key for Additional File Security*** - If selected, recipients require an access key to upload the requested file. Instructions for requesting the access key is included in the message the recipient receives.  
7. Click the ***OK***button.  
8. Click the ***Send***button. This:  
	* Sends an email to your inbox confirming that the Large File Send invitation message has been sent to the recipient.  
	* Sends the recipient an email containing an attachment. Once opened, the attachment contains complete instructions on how to send the Large File Send attachment as requested:  
	![Mimecast for Outlook Requesting Large File Attachments_1](https://community.mimecast.com/servlet/rtaImage?eid=ka03l000000zGeC&feoid=00N3l00000FQXUa&refid=0EM3l000002SRzv)  
  
  
Uploading an Attachment  
-----------------------  
  
  
![Mimecast for Outlook Requesting Large File Attachments_1](https://community.mimecast.com/servlet/rtaImage?eid=ka03l000000zGeC&feoid=00N3l00000FQXUa&refid=0EM3l000002SRzw)  
  
  
If you have been requested to upload a file using Large File Send:  
  
  
1. Open the message you'll receive from the sender.  
2. Open the ***Mimecast Large File Send Instructions*** attachment.  
3. Click on the ***Upload Files*** link in the attachment. The Large File Send portal is opened in your browser.  
4. If the sender has requested you get an access key, click the ***Get Access Key***button. An access key is emailed to your email address.  
  
|           |                                                        |
| --------- | ------------------------------------------------------ |
| **Note:** | If an access key was not requested, proceed to step 6. |
5. Copy and paste the access key into the ***Enter Access Key*** field.  
6. Click the ***Log In*** button.  
7. Click the ***Add Files*** button to select the files to attach.  
8. Select the required files, and click the ***Open***button.  
9. Optionally, add a message in the ***Add Message*** section.  
10. Click the ***Send***button. A message is displayed in the portal when the message has been sent, and the portal can be closed.  
  
  
**ESCALATION:**  
  
  
If unable to send or receive attachments escalate to Mimecast queue.  
  
[This is a link to the full ServiceNow article](https://refinitiv.service-now.com/sp/?id=kb_article&sys_id=63ec5b2787d8fd50b173c88f8bbb3525)
title: testets
body:
Mimecast for Outlook: Sending/Requesting Attachments via Large File Send

You can request a message recipient to send attachments safely and securely via Large File Receive.

You can send attachments safely and securely via Large File Send in Mimecast for Outlook.
Note: From Mimecast for Outlook v7.1, the maximum number of attachments that can be attached to a message using Large File Send is 100. If you have more than 100 attachments, we recommend using a ZIP archive.
Sending Attachments via Large File Send

To send attachments via Large File Send from the Microsoft Outlook client :

  1. Create a Message.
  2. Click on the Mimecast tab.
  3. Click on the Attach Large Files icon.
  4. Select the Files you want to attach.

| | | | --------- | -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | Note: | The selected files are attached to the message with a notification that they will be sent via Large File Send. The file extensions are changes to .LFS meaning you can't preview them. If you want to ensure you're sending the correct files, check them before selecting them. | 5. Click the Send button.
6. Amend the Large File Send options as required:
Note: Your administrator may enforce some or all of these settings, meaning you cannot override them.

| Field / Option | Description | | ---------------------------------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | Expiry Access to the Files After | Select the expiry date of the Large File Send request from the drop down. The actual expiry date is displayed to the right of the field. Once the specified date has been reached, the file can no longer be accessed via Large File Send. The "Custom" option al- lows you to set an expiry date that doesn't fit any of the other options (e.g. 28 days) but the specified value cannot be more than 90 days. | | Notify Me When the Files are Accessed | If selected, you are notified when the recipient accesses the files via the Large File Send portal. | | Send me a Link to the Files | If selected, you are sent a link to the files in the Large File Send portal. | | Invite Recipients to Send me Large Files | If selected, the recipient can send file attachments back to you via Large File Send. They don't have to be Mimecast customers to do this. This functionality is useful when sending a file for comment or approval. | | Use an Access Key for Additional File Security | If selected, the recipient must authenticate themselves by using an access key, sent to them by the Large File Send portal, before being able to access the files. | 7. Click on the Sendbutton. A progress notification popup dialog is displayed. This automatically closes when the message is successfully sent, and a notification popup message is displayed.

Requesting Large File Attachments Benefits
  • A message recipient doesn't need to be a Mimecast for Outlook or even a Mimecast user. They'll receive instructions in the message to upload the files to the Large File Send portal.
  • Increased file security can be added by getting recipients to request an access key to access the Large File Receive portal. The key is emailed to the recipient's email address and must be entered to access the portal

To request a large file to be sent:

  1. Click on New Email to create a message as normal.
  2. Click on the Mimecastribbon.
  3. Click on the Request Large Files icon.
  4. Enter the recipient's Email Address and add a subject.
  5. Click on the Sendbutton. The Large File Receive dialog displays.
  6. Complete the dialog as required:
    • Expire Access to Files After - All requests to share large files are subject to a time limit. Specify a value from the drop down list to specify the time frame recipients have to access the requested file. Once that period has passed, recipients are unable to access the file.
    • Use an Access Key for Additional File Security - If selected, recipients require an access key to upload the requested file. Instructions for requesting the access key is included in the message the recipient receives.
  7. Click the OKbutton.
  8. Click the Sendbutton. This:
    • Sends an email to your inbox confirming that the Large File Send invitation message has been sent to the recipient.
    • Sends the recipient an email containing an attachment. Once opened, the attachment contains complete instructions on how to send the Large File Send attachment as requested:
Uploading an Attachment

If you have been requested to upload a file using Large File Send:

  1. Open the message you'll receive from the sender.
  2. Open the Mimecast Large File Send Instructions attachment.
  3. Click on the Upload Files link in the attachment. The Large File Send portal is opened in your browser.
  4. If the sender has requested you get an access key, click the Get Access Keybutton. An access key is emailed to your email address.

| | | | --------- | ------------------------------------------------------ | | Note: | If an access key was not requested, proceed to step 6. | 5. Copy and paste the access key into the Enter Access Key field.
6. Click the Log In button.
7. Click the Add Files button to select the files to attach.
8. Select the required files, and click the Openbutton.
9. Optionally, add a message in the Add Message section.
10. Click the Sendbutton. A message is displayed in the portal when the message has been sent, and the portal can be closed.

ESCALATION:

If unable to send or receive attachments escalate to Mimecast queue.

This is a link to the full ServiceNow article

body_markdown:
**PLEASE NOTE - This KB is only applicable for the machines connected to TEN domain and won't apply for machines that are on Autopilot.**

**Support Notes**

## HI

<h1> Hi </h1> 

`<XX>`

· This only applies to Windows 10 devices that are enrolled in Refinitiv Microsoft BitLocker Administration and Monitoring (MBAM) Drive Encryption

· Use this tool to help users to unlock their hard drive from locked out situation

· **User domain password will not be reset** with this procedure

· Verify security questions and answers before unlocking of BitLocker

· Advanced Help Desk access requires:

· Support agent’s TEN\\AU account must have proper AD group membership

· Support agent’s web browser be launched with their TEN\\AU account

· Advanced Help Desk is only for use when using accessing as a standard Help Desk user is unable to retrieve the Recovery Key for a workstation due to no/incorrect MBAM listed ‘Device User’.

**[Resolution](https://thomsonreuters.service-now.com/sp?id=kb_article&sys_id=04c0aafcdb746fc057b25d30cf9619ad)**
=

The BitLocker recover screen can be seen below showing the location of the Recover key ID information that will be needed from the customer.

Retrieve\*\*[Recovery Key](https://thomsonreuters.service-now.com/sp?id=kb_article&sys_id=04c0aafcdb746fc057b25d30cf9619ad)\*\*
=

1. Agent opens web browser using their TEN\\AU account

2. Agent connects to web address: <http://c288sdembam1.ten.thomsonreuters.com/helpdesk/KeyRecoveryPage.aspx>

3. Agent enters the first 8 characters of the ‘Recovery key ID” provided by the customer into the Key ID field.

![](https://refinitiv.service-now.com/sys_attachment.do?sys_id=495aeedadb629410d77b4a28139619c2)

4\.Agent verifies the what was done prior to this issue happening to determine plausible reason for lockout, then selects the appropriate option under Reason for Drive Unlock. Once the reason is determined, select it from the dropdown list.

![](https://refinitiv.service-now.com/sys_attachment.do?sys_id=cd5aeedadb629410d77b4a28139619f5)  
NOTE: The most common reasons are likely “Operating System files modified”, “BIOS changed” and “Lost PIN”. If unknown, select Operating System files modified.

1. Operating System Boot Order changed

2. BIOS changed

3. Operating System files modified

4. Lost Startup Key

5. Lost PIN

6. TPM Reset

7. Lost Passphrase

8. Lost Smartcard

9. Other

5\.Agent clicks Submit.

![](https://refinitiv.service-now.com/sys_attachment.do?sys_id=495aeedadb629410d77b4a28139619f7)

NOTE: If recovery key is not found or the user is not valid for the drive, verify that the information entered for User Domain, User ID, and Key ID are correct. If the caller is noted by BitLocker as a user of the workstation, then the customer that is the user of the workstation will need to request the Recovery Key.

GSD provides the customer with the 48-digit Drive Recovery Key provided. The key is numerical only and is made of 8 sets of 6 numbers and the hyphens are not typed

\<XXXXXX-XXXXXX-XXXXXX-XXXXXX-XXXXXX-XXXXXX-XXXXXX-XXXXXX\>

![](https://refinitiv.service-now.com/sys_attachment.do?sys_id=3ec73592db227450005c0704ca9619a1)  
7\.After putting in the Recovery Key on the affected workstation, customer should press the Enter key.

8\.Windows should continue to load.

**For GSD:**

· Service Desk Analyst or Workplace Engineers who do not have access to the MBAM HelpDesk web address: <http://c288sdembam1.ten.thomsonreuters.com/helpdesk/KeyRecoveryPage.aspx>

· Add the user's U ID (UEmp ID) to group TEN-DG-APP-MBAM-GSD-ALL

**Escalation:**

TCS- REMOTE-SUPPORT or TCS-TECHBAR (if necessary) \>\> TCS-APP-MALWARE

[This is a link to the full ServiceNow article](https://refinitiv.service-now.com/sp/?id=kb_article&sys_id=aab7f192db227450005c0704ca9619d9)

body:
PLEASE NOTE - This KB is only applicable for the machines connected to TEN domain and won't apply for machines that are on Autopilot.

Support Notes

HI

Hi

<XX>

· This only applies to Windows 10 devices that are enrolled in Refinitiv Microsoft BitLocker Administration and Monitoring (MBAM) Drive Encryption

· Use this tool to help users to unlock their hard drive from locked out situation

· User domain password will not be reset with this procedure

· Verify security questions and answers before unlocking of BitLocker

· Advanced Help Desk access requires:

· Support agent’s TEN\AU account must have proper AD group membership

· Support agent’s web browser be launched with their TEN\AU account

· Advanced Help Desk is only for use when using accessing as a standard Help Desk user is unable to retrieve the Recovery Key for a workstation due to no/incorrect MBAM listed ‘Device User’.

Resolution

The BitLocker recover screen can be seen below showing the location of the Recover key ID information that will be needed from the customer.

Retrieve**Recovery Key**

  1. Agent opens web browser using their TEN\AU account

  2. Agent connects to web address: http://c288sdembam1.ten.thomsonreuters.com/helpdesk/KeyRecoveryPage.aspx

  3. Agent enters the first 8 characters of the ‘Recovery key ID” provided by the customer into the Key ID field.

4.Agent verifies the what was done prior to this issue happening to determine plausible reason for lockout, then selects the appropriate option under Reason for Drive Unlock. Once the reason is determined, select it from the dropdown list.


NOTE: The most common reasons are likely “Operating System files modified”, “BIOS changed” and “Lost PIN”. If unknown, select Operating System files modified.

  1. Operating System Boot Order changed

  2. BIOS changed

  3. Operating System files modified

  4. Lost Startup Key

  5. Lost PIN

  6. TPM Reset

  7. Lost Passphrase

  8. Lost Smartcard

  9. Other

5.Agent clicks Submit.

NOTE: If recovery key is not found or the user is not valid for the drive, verify that the information entered for User Domain, User ID, and Key ID are correct. If the caller is noted by BitLocker as a user of the workstation, then the customer that is the user of the workstation will need to request the Recovery Key.

GSD provides the customer with the 48-digit Drive Recovery Key provided. The key is numerical only and is made of 8 sets of 6 numbers and the hyphens are not typed

<XXXXXX-XXXXXX-XXXXXX-XXXXXX-XXXXXX-XXXXXX-XXXXXX-XXXXXX>


7.After putting in the Recovery Key on the affected workstation, customer should press the Enter key.

8.Windows should continue to load.

For GSD:

· Service Desk Analyst or Workplace Engineers who do not have access to the MBAM HelpDesk web address: http://c288sdembam1.ten.thomsonreuters.com/helpdesk/KeyRecoveryPage.aspx

· Add the user's U ID (UEmp ID) to group TEN-DG-APP-MBAM-GSD-ALL

Escalation:

TCS- REMOTE-SUPPORT or TCS-TECHBAR (if necessary) >> TCS-APP-MALWARE

This is a link to the full ServiceNow article

body_markdown: An article should have a body that expands the information about the topic. For instance, authors should write several body paragraphs that explain the main issue under analysis. In this case, body paragraphs should explain the main idea of an article in more detail, expounding on its introduction. In turn, people must start each body paragraph with a clear topic sentence since they need to explain a single idea in every section to make their articles clear and relevant. Thus, writing a good article should have clear body paragraphs that include more details on the title and opening paragraph.. Source: https://wr1ter.com/how-to-write-an-article
title: How to write an article - API Test

body_markdown:
The content from the provided URL is a discussion about a C++ code snippet. The code creates a class called `LambdaStore` that stores a lambda function. This function is called once in the constructor of the class and prints `11.1` without any issues. However, when the same function is called again later in the method `ExecuteStoredLambda`, the program crashes. The user is seeking an explanation for this behavior, questioning if the lambda function has a limited lifespan.

---
**This article was added by PlusOne on behalf of Nishikant Dhanuka**
title: Understanding the Lifespan of Lambda Functions in C++: A Discussion on Unexpected Crashes
body:
The content from the provided URL is a discussion about a C++ code snippet. The code creates a class called LambdaStore that stores a lambda function. This function is called once in the constructor of the class and prints 11.1 without any issues. However, when the same function is called again later in the method ExecuteStoredLambda, the program crashes. The user is seeking an explanation for this behavior, questioning if the lambda function has a limited lifespan.

This article was added by PlusOne on behalf of Nishikant Dhanuka

body_markdown:
Changing your DNS A record can potentially impact your emails, especially if you're using Autodiscovery in Outlook. If your email is with 365, it's unlikely to be an issue since 365 is one of the first places Outlook checks for an Autodiscover response. However, if your email is hosted elsewhere, such as MS Exchange via another company, and the service uses Autodiscover domains, HTTP redirects, or SRV data to distribute the Autodiscover information to Outlook, you may encounter issues unless you take manual steps. This is because Outlook will check your domain for Autodiscover information, and if it receives an answer from the hosting, even if it's not valid, Outlook will stop trying the other steps and can fail to autodiscover the email account. This can occur if the hosting includes email and is configured to think it's authoritative for email on the domain. Please note that the impact might differ based on the context of your specific setup.

---
**This article was added by PlusOne on behalf of Nishikant Dhanuka**
title: Potential Impact of Changing DNS A Record on Email Autodiscovery in Outlook
body:
Changing your DNS A record can potentially impact your emails, especially if you're using Autodiscovery in Outlook. If your email is with 365, it's unlikely to be an issue since 365 is one of the first places Outlook checks for an Autodiscover response. However, if your email is hosted elsewhere, such as MS Exchange via another company, and the service uses Autodiscover domains, HTTP redirects, or SRV data to distribute the Autodiscover information to Outlook, you may encounter issues unless you take manual steps. This is because Outlook will check your domain for Autodiscover information, and if it receives an answer from the hosting, even if it's not valid, Outlook will stop trying the other steps and can fail to autodiscover the email account. This can occur if the hosting includes email and is configured to think it's authoritative for email on the domain. Please note that the impact might differ based on the context of your specific setup.

This article was added by PlusOne on behalf of Nishikant Dhanuka

Sure, here's a draft for an apology message:

\`\`\`
Dear StackOverflow Team,

I am writing to express my sincere apologies for the recent incident where our testing activities inadvertently resulted in spamming your test environment.

We understand the inconvenience this may have caused and we deeply regret any disruption to your operations. It was never our intention to cause any harm or inconvenience. The incident was a result of an oversight in our testing procedures, and we are taking immediate steps to rectify this.

We are committed to ensuring that this does not happen again. We are reviewing our testing protocols and implementing stricter controls to prevent any future occurrences. We value our relationship with StackOverflow and we are dedicated to maintaining the highest level of respect and cooperation.

Once again, we apologize for any inconvenience caused and appreciate your understanding and patience in this matter.

Best Regards,
<Your Name>
<Your Position>
\`\`\`

Please replace `<Your Name>` and `<Your Position>` with your actual name and position.

body_markdown:
Sure, you can use the Hough Circle Transform method in OpenCV to detect circles in an image. Here's a brief Python code snippet that demonstrates this:

\`\`\`python
import cv2
import numpy as np

# Load the image
img = cv2.imread('image.jpg', cv2.IMREAD_COLOR)

# Convert it to grayscale
gray = cv2.cvtColor(img, cv2.COLOR_BGR2GRAY)

# Apply a blur to reduce noise
gray = cv2.medianBlur(gray, 5)

# Perform the Hough Circle Transform
circles = cv2.HoughCircles(gray, cv2.HOUGH_GRADIENT, 1, 20, param1=50, param2=30, minRadius=0, maxRadius=0)

# If circles are detected
if circles is not None:
    circles = np.uint16(np.around(circles))
    for i in circles[0, :]:
        # Draw the outer circle
        cv2.circle(img, (i[0], i[1]), i[2], (0, 255, 0), 2)
        # Draw the center of the circle
        cv2.circle(img, (i[0], i[1]), 2, (0, 0, 255), 3)

# Display the image with detected circles
cv2.imshow('Detected Circles', img)
cv2.waitKey(0)
cv2.destroyAllWindows()
\`\`\`

This code reads an image, converts it to grayscale, applies a blur to reduce noise, and then uses the `cv2.HoughCircles()` function to detect the circles. The detected circles are then drawn on the original image and the image is displayed.

Please replace `'image.jpg'` with the path to your image file.

---
**This article was added by PlusOne on behalf of Zvonimir Bednarcik**
title: Using Hough Circle Transform in OpenCV to Detect Circles in an Image: A Python Code Example
body:
Sure, you can use the Hough Circle Transform method in OpenCV to detect circles in an image. Here's a brief Python code snippet that demonstrates this:

```python import cv2 import numpy as np

Load the image

img = cv2.imread('image.jpg', cv2.IMREAD_COLOR)

Convert it to grayscale

gray = cv2.cvtColor(img, cv2.COLOR_BGR2GRAY)

Apply a blur to reduce noise

gray = cv2.medianBlur(gray, 5)

Perform the Hough Circle Transform

circles = cv2.HoughCircles(gray, cv2.HOUGH_GRADIENT, 1, 20, param1=50, param2=30, minRadius=0, maxRadius=0)

If circles are detected

if circles is not None: circles = np.uint16(np.around(circles)) for i in circles[0, :]: # Draw the outer circle cv2.circle(img, (i[0], i[1]), i[2], (0, 255, 0), 2) # Draw the center of the circle cv2.circle(img, (i[0], i[1]), 2, (0, 0, 255), 3)

Display the image with detected circles

cv2.imshow('Detected Circles', img) cv2.waitKey(0) cv2.destroyAllWindows() ```

This code reads an image, converts it to grayscale, applies a blur to reduce noise, and then uses the cv2.HoughCircles() function to detect the circles. The detected circles are then drawn on the original image and the image is displayed.

Please replace 'image.jpg' with the path to your image file.

This article was added by PlusOne on behalf of Zvonimir Bednarcik

body_markdown:
Sure, <@U051AC09738>. Here's a brief guide on how to connect to an EC2 instance using SSH:

1. **Open your terminal**: You can use any terminal emulator of your choice.

2. **Navigate to the directory containing your private key**: This is the `.pem` file that you got when you created your EC2 instance. You can navigate to the directory using the `cd` command. For example, if your key is in the Downloads folder, you would type `cd Downloads`.

3. **Set the permissions for your private key file**: AWS requires your private key file to not be publicly viewable. You can set the permissions using the `chmod` command. For example, if your key file is named `my-key-pair.pem`, you would type `chmod 400 my-key-pair.pem`.

4. **Connect to your EC2 instance**: You can connect using the `ssh` command. You'll need the public DNS of your EC2 instance, which you can find in the EC2 console. The command will look something like this: `ssh -i "my-key-pair.pem" ec2-user@ec2-198-51-100-1.compute-1.amazonaws.com`.

Please replace `"my-key-pair.pem"` and `"ec2-user@ec2-198-51-100-1.compute-1.amazonaws.com"` with your actual key file name and EC2 instance DNS respectively.

Remember, the default user name is `ec2-user` for Amazon Linux instances and `ubuntu` for Ubuntu instances. If you're using a different AMI, the user name might be different.

Let me know if you need more help!

---
**This article was added by PlusOne on behalf of Zvonimir Bednarcik**
title: Step-by-Step Guide to Connecting to an EC2 Instance Using SSH
body:
Sure, <@U051AC09738>. Here's a brief guide on how to connect to an EC2 instance using SSH:

  1. Open your terminal: You can use any terminal emulator of your choice.

  2. Navigate to the directory containing your private key: This is the .pem file that you got when you created your EC2 instance. You can navigate to the directory using the cd command. For example, if your key is in the Downloads folder, you would type cd Downloads.

  3. Set the permissions for your private key file: AWS requires your private key file to not be publicly viewable. You can set the permissions using the chmod command. For example, if your key file is named my-key-pair.pem, you would type chmod 400 my-key-pair.pem.

  4. Connect to your EC2 instance: You can connect using the ssh command. You'll need the public DNS of your EC2 instance, which you can find in the EC2 console. The command will look something like this: ssh -i "my-key-pair.pem" ec2-user@ec2-198-51-100-1.compute-1.amazonaws.com.

Please replace "my-key-pair.pem" and "ec2-user@ec2-198-51-100-1.compute-1.amazonaws.com" with your actual key file name and EC2 instance DNS respectively.

Remember, the default user name is ec2-user for Amazon Linux instances and ubuntu for Ubuntu instances. If you're using a different AMI, the user name might be different.

Let me know if you need more help!

body_markdown:
In the year of fourteen fifty-three,
Constantinople fell, a sight to see.
The Byzantine Empire's final stand,
Against the Ottomans, a force so grand.

The city walls, once tall and proud,
Echoed with the battle, loud.
Cannon fire and warrior's cry,
Underneath the darkened sky.

Mehmed the Conqueror, his name would be,
Led the siege, fierce as the sea.
The Theodosian walls did break,
For the Ottoman Empire's sake.

Constantine XI, brave and bold,
Fought for his city, as foretold.
But alas, the city fell,
In history's heart, the tale we tell.

The Byzantine era, it did end,
A new chapter, the Ottomans penned.
Constantinople, now Istanbul,
A tale of power, push and pull.

---
**This article was added by PlusOne on behalf of Zvonimir Bednarcik**
title: The Fall of Constantinople: A Poetic Retelling of History
body:
In the year of fourteen fifty-three, Constantinople fell, a sight to see. The Byzantine Empire's final stand, Against the Ottomans, a force so grand.

The city walls, once tall and proud, Echoed with the battle, loud. Cannon fire and warrior's cry, Underneath the darkened sky.

Mehmed the Conqueror, his name would be, Led the siege, fierce as the sea. The Theodosian walls did break, For the Ottoman Empire's sake.

Constantine XI, brave and bold, Fought for his city, as foretold. But alas, the city fell, In history's heart, the tale we tell.

The Byzantine era, it did end, A new chapter, the Ottomans penned. Constantinople, now Istanbul, A tale of power, push and pull.

This article was added by PlusOne on behalf of Zvonimir Bednarcik
